item.title: TalkSwitch Supports both VoIP and Legacy PBX
item.description: Choosing between a traditional phone system (analog or digital TDM PBX) and a newer VoIP system can be tough. TalkSwitch offers a solution by supporting both technologies. For example, the TalkSwitch 244vs desktop PBX handles 2 incoming lines, 4 extensions for analog phones, and features like voicemail and music on hold. It also supports 10 remote extensions, allowing cell phones, home phones, and phones on other systems to connect by dialing a 3-digit extension.

item.title: Private Branch Exchange Connections
item.description: PBX telephone systems are the preferred business phone technology for medium and large businesses, though recent advancements have made them affordable for smaller companies as well, replacing outdated hardwired or key systems. If you’re considering a new PBX system, reaching out to VAR Network can provide insights into pricing and available options. Beyond hardware, PBX systems require connectivity, with various options offering different cost and performance benefits. The most basic connection is an FXO, or analog phone line, connecting to a central office.

item.title: When Your Broadband Isn’t Stable Enough For VoIP Phones
item.description: By: John Shepler You might get laughed at for sticking with your old-school analog phone lines. “Still using a rotary phone?” they’ll joke. But here’s the thing: those old-fashioned phone lines were built for clear sound and unwavering reliability. Sure, they might deteriorate over time, leading to static and eventually dropped calls. A quick fix from the phone company, though, and you’re back in business for years to come. The modern approach is using the internet for phone calls, combining your phone and internet services onto one broadband connection.

item.title: Enterprise VoIP Moves to the Cloud
item.description: by: John Shepler For decades, enterprise VoIP has been taking the place of traditional analog business phone systems. While PBX systems evolved into IP PBX, they remained hardware and software bound to a physical location. Now, those telecom rooms are becoming vacant as business VoIP transitions to the cloud and evolves into Unified Communications. What’s Cloud Got To Do With It? Initially, businesses set up their own phone switching systems when the limited buttons on desk phones became insufficient.
